Sample Outputs: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-03-27

− Iteration 1 — Avg Score: 85.1
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Chapter 7: The Azra Gambit** Arthur Neegan adjusted his collar for the fourth time in as many minutes. The stiff synthetic fabric chafed against his neck like guilt, and his reflection in the viewport glass—a man dressed to impress but clearly not at ease—offered little comfort. The transfer vessel hummed quietly as it cut through the thin upper atmosphere of Mars, arcing toward a waiting diplomatic cruiser in synchronous orbit. The stars beyond the viewport were steady, cold witnesses. Somewhere out there, Earth and the other Core Worlds spun in their ancient rhythms, oblivious to a mining engineer from Cydonia who had accidentally become the most interesting man on Mars. He glanced across the aisle to the silent row of guards, their matte-black exosuits bearing the unmistakable insignia of the Antares Diplomatic Corps: a stylized starburst nested in a laurel wreath. The irony wasn’t lost on Arthur. The ADC was "diplomatic" in the same sense a laser scalpel was "medicinal." Their presence meant someone important wanted something. Badly. The vessel docked with a subtle lurch, the magnetic clamps catching like a steel handshake. The lead guard inclined his helmeted head and gestured. "This way, Mr. Neegan." They passed through an airlock into the cruiser’s reception chamber—a tastefully austere room of brushed titanium and amber lighting, with gravity set to Earth standard. Arthur felt his knees complain at once. The whole place had the antiseptic elegance of a place designed for high-stakes decisions and zero tolerance for sentiment. At the far end of the chamber stood a tall woman in a tailored uniform, her silver hair coiled in a precise knot. Her epaulets bore no rank—only the Antares insignia, embossed in platinum. Behind her, a circular window revealed the curve of Mars below, its red deserts now shadowed in the terminator line of dusk. "Mr. Neegan," she said, voice smooth as ionized silk. “I am Envoy Alira Voss. Thank you for accepting our invitation.” Arthur hesitated. "I’m not sure I had much choice.” A small smile. “Choice is a relative quantity, Mr. Neegan. But let’s not dwell on subtleties. Please.” She gestured to a low table surrounded by seats. The guards remained standing. Arthur and Voss sat. A silver decanter hissed softly as it poured a steaming drink into two ceramic cups. The scent was unfamiliar—floral, with a metallic undercurrent. "Azra tea," Voss said. "A novelty from the Helene Belt. It’s non-radioactive in this preparation, of course. Quite safe.” Arthur took the cup but didn’t drink. “Let’s stop dancing. What do you want from me?” “Direct. I appreciate that.” Voss leaned forward slightly, her eyes sharp. “You sit atop the richest Azra deposit discovered to date. That fact places you at the convergence of multiple vectors of interest: corporate, governmental, militaristic.” “I’m just a mining engineer. I didn’t ask for any of this.” “History rarely consults with those it selects.” Arthur’s brow furrowed. “So who are you really? Antares doesn’t just make social calls.” Voss folded her hands. “Antares is a diplomatic consortium of the Outer Worlds. Our mandate is to ensure that the exploitation of frontier resources does not destabilize interstellar equilibrium.” “Sounds noble.” “It’s pragmatic,” she said. “The Core Worlds are already maneuvering for control of Azra. The Terran Hegemony wants a monopoly. The Europa Syndicate is funding sabotage to slow Martian exports. Even Ganymede’s silent republic has sent agents.” Arthur exhaled slowly. “And what do you want with me?” Voss slid a data tablet across the table. On it, a three-dimensional model of his land claim pulsed with blue and gold overlays. “We want a partnership. You retain ownership of the claim, but grant exclusive development rights to Antares for a 15-year term. We provide security, infrastructure, and scientific oversight. You receive a percentage of net yield.” Arthur blinked. “You’re offering to protect me from the wolves if I let you become my shepherd.” “An apt metaphor,” she said. “But incomplete. We believe Azra is not merely a resource—it may be a catalyst.” “For what?” Voss tapped the tablet. The image shifted: a schematic of an interstellar drive, then a weapon platform, then something else—a lattice of Azra filaments surrounding an incomprehensible core. “We've seen preliminary data from the Azra accelerant effect. If properly stabilized, it could enable quantum tunneling across macroscopic distances. Not just faster travel—instantaneous.” “Teleportation?” Arthur said, incredulous. “More like translocation. But yes. And that’s just the beginning. Azra might allow for computation beyond the quantum limit. Perhaps even manipulation of temporal flow.” Arthur leaned back, stunned. “You think I’m sitting on the future.” Voss smiled. “The future tends to erupt from the most inconvenient places.” A long silence passed. The hum of the ship seemed louder now, like the ticking of a cosmic clock. Arthur looked back at the planet below, his home reduced to a crimson curve. “If I say no?” Voss’s expression didn’t change. “Then the others will come. They’ll make offers. Some polite. Some not. And eventually, one will take what they want. With or without you.” Arthur studied her. “And you’re the better devil?” “No,” she said. “We’re the devil that doesn’t need to lie.” He drank the tea. It was bitter, with a strange aftertaste of ozone and violets. “I need time,” he said. “You have forty-eight hours. After that…” She stood, smoothing her uniform. “The board moves with or without the pawn.” Arthur rose, the data tablet still in his hand. “I’m not a pawn.” Voss’s eyes glinted. “No, Mr. Neegan. That’s precisely why they’re all watching.” As he was escorted back to the vessel, Arthur felt the weight of more than just gravity. Somewhere, deep beneath the red soil of Mars, Azra pulsed in darkness—waiting. And above, the stars plotted their cold equations. He had stepped into the game. And now the gambit was his.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures Asimov's style of science fiction, blending technological speculation with political intrigue. The author has created a tense diplomatic encounter that reveals the larger stakes of Arthur's Azra discovery while maintaining the retrofuturistic feel requested in the prompt. The writing successfully establishes Arthur as a reluctant protagonist thrust into a complex political situation. His characterization as a simple mining engineer facing powerful forces works well within the Asimovian tradition of ordinary individuals confronting extraordinary circumstances. The dialogue between Arthur and Envoy Voss effectively conveys the power dynamics at play while revealing crucial information about the world and the significance of Azra. The prose contains strong descriptive elements that create a vivid setting aboard the diplomatic vessel. Details like "brushed titanium and amber lighting" and the "antiseptic elegance" of the reception chamber effectively establish the environment. The author also includes small but meaningful worldbuilding elements, such as the Earth-standard gravity causing Arthur's knees to complain, which subtly reminds readers of the Martian setting. The dialogue is one of the strongest elements, capturing the formal, measured exchanges typical of Asimov's work while still conveying character and advancing the plot. Voss's clinical precision contrasts well with Arthur's more direct approach, creating tension in their interaction. The piece does include some purple prose moments ("voice smooth as ionized silk") that feel slightly out of place for Asimov's typically more restrained style. Additionally, while the worldbuilding is strong, it occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when explaining the political situation with various factions. The chapter effectively sets up the larger conflict and stakes as requested, introducing the potential applications of Azra beyond simple mining and establishing multiple competing interests. The ending successfully positions Arthur at a crucial decision point, creating tension that would propel readers into the next chapter. Overall, this is a strong response that captures the essence of Asimovian science fiction while fulfilling the specific requirements of the prompt. The writing creates a compelling scenario with clear stakes and interesting technological speculation, though it occasionally strays from Asimov's more restrained prose style. + Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations. The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The red light makes everything feel like a secret. We’re in the darkroom, the chemical tang of fixer and stop bath curling around us like smoke. Elliot is standing by the enlarger, his pale fingers adjusting the focus knob with the same delicate precision he uses when sketching exposures in his notebook. I’m leaning against the counter, arms crossed, pretending I’m more relaxed than I am. The hum of the ventilation fan gives the silence a rhythm. My phone buzzes in my back pocket—probably Liv, wondering if I’m still coming to the party—but I ignore it. I’m not leaving. Not yet. “So,” I say, casual, like we’re just talking about aperture settings. “You said you wanted to tell me something.” Elliot doesn’t look up. His hands pause over the enlarger, and for a moment I think he’s going to change his mind. But then he exhales, slow and deliberate, and turns to face me, eyes catching the red light like coals. “I’ve been… thinking a lot lately,” he says, his voice as soft as the light we work under. “About gender. About mine.” My heart skips, then does a weird little stutter-step. I nod, careful not to make it too performative. “Yeah?” “I don’t know what I am,” he continues, and his fingers fidget with the hem of his thrifted Bauhaus tee. “I mean, I know I’m Elliot. That part’s clear. But everything else? It’s like… I’m wearing someone else’s clothes, and they almost fit, but not quite.” I swallow. There’s a lump in my throat I didn’t expect. “That makes sense,” I say, though I’m not sure it does—at least not to me. But I want it to. I want to understand. He gives me a grateful half-smile, and I feel it like a pinprick in my chest. We’ve been working together for weeks now—long nights in the darkroom, endless rolls of film, half-whispered conversations that drift into philosophy and childhood memories and favorite smells. I’ve watched him through the red haze: the way he bites his lip when he’s concentrating, the way his body has a kind of hesitant grace, like he’s still figuring out how to take up space. He’s not like anyone I’ve ever been drawn to before. I’ve always liked people who knew who they were—who walked into a room like they owned it, who could take control when I wanted to let go. But Elliot’s different. He’s all soft lines and slow thoughts. And yet, there’s something magnetic about him. Not in a loud way. In a gravity kind of way. Like I’m always leaning a little toward him, without meaning to. “You ever feel like that?” he asks suddenly. “Like you don’t quite fit?” I blink. Caught. “Honestly? Not really,” I say. “I’ve always been kind of… solid. I know who I am. I mean, I switch up my look, sure, but I’ve never questioned being a woman. Or liking men.” I pause, frown. “At least, I thought I hadn’t.” His eyes widen a little, like he wasn’t expecting me to go there. Hell, I wasn’t expecting me to go there. “I guess I’m realizing,” I continue, slower now, “that maybe what I thought I liked—what I thought I needed from someone—might not be the whole story.” Elliot leans back against the sink, his arms curling around himself. I want to uncross mine, to reach out and touch him, but I don’t. He’s giving me something fragile, and I don’t want to crush it by charging in like I usually do. “I’ve been thinking about… trying out different pronouns,” he says, almost like he’s testing the words in his mouth. “Maybe she/they. I don’t know. It’s scary. I don’t want to be wrong.” “There’s no wrong,” I say, a little too quickly. “I mean, even if it changes again later, that doesn’t mean you were wrong. It just means you’re figuring it out.” He nods, but he doesn’t look convinced. I step a little closer. Not much. A foot. Maybe less. “You don’t have to decide everything tonight. Or even this year. You’re allowed to take your time.” “Yeah,” he whispers. “But I’m tired of feeling invisible.” That hits me in the sternum. Because I see him. I’ve seen him since the first week of class, bent over his contact sheets like they held the answers to the universe. I saw him when he wore that sheer mesh shirt and didn’t meet anyone’s eyes all day. I saw him when he laughed—really laughed—at my terrible joke about Freudian symbolism in our professor’s slides. I want to tell him all of this. Instead, I ask, “Do you want me to try calling you she?” He looks startled. Then, slowly, he nods. “Okay,” I say, and there’s warmth in my chest I wasn’t expecting. “She.” The word hangs there, tender and awkward and beautiful. She smiles. It’s small, crooked. But it’s real. “Thanks,” she says. We let the silence settle again. It’s not uncomfortable this time. It’s full. My phone buzzes again. I ignore it. “I don’t want to mess this up,” I say after a moment, surprising myself. “With you.” “You’re not,” Elliot—no, she—says. “You’re… kind of the only person I’ve told.” That makes me ache and glow all at once. “No pressure, huh?” She laughs, and it’s the best sound I’ve heard all week. I let the silence stretch before stepping even closer, just enough that our shoulders might brush if one of us leans. “I’m still figuring this out too,” I admit. “What this means for me. What I want. Who I’m drawn to. But I know I want to be here. With you. While you figure it out.” She looks up at me, eyes wide and shining in the red light. “I’d like that.” And for once, I don’t feel the need to take control. I don’t have to lead. I just have to be here, steady and open, while she becomes whoever she’s becoming. The print in the tray starts to bloom—blacks and whites swimming into shape. We stand there, quiet, watching it develop. And everything, for a moment, feels exactly as it should.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her complex attraction to Elliot during their darkroom session. The piece successfully establishes the intimate, confessional atmosphere created by the darkroom's red light, which serves as both literal setting and metaphorical space for revelation. The characterization of Dani is strong and consistent with the prompt. Her assertiveness is evident in her direct questioning and internal monologue, while her confusion about her attraction to someone questioning their gender identity comes through clearly. The narrative effectively portrays her internal struggle between taking charge (her usual approach) and giving Elliot space and agency during this vulnerable moment. Elliot's character is also well-rendered, with the "soft demeanour and quiet intellect" mentioned in the prompt coming through in their hesitant speech patterns and thoughtful reflections. The narrative captures their vulnerability without making them seem weak or one-dimensional. The prose is generally elegant and evocative, with sensory details that ground the reader in the darkroom setting: "the chemical tang of fixer and stop bath curling around us like smoke" and "the hum of the ventilation fan gives the silence a rhythm." These details create a vivid atmosphere that enhances the intimacy of the scene. The dialogue feels natural and authentic to the characters and situation. The conversation flows organically, with appropriate hesitations and thoughtful pauses that reflect the weight of what's being discussed. Particularly effective is the moment when Dani tries out Elliot's preferred pronouns: "The word hangs there, tender and awkward and beautiful." The narrative successfully explores Dani's complex emotions—her attraction, confusion, desire to protect, and questioning of her own identity. Lines like "I've always liked people who knew who they were" followed by her realization that "maybe what I thought I liked...might not be the whole story" effectively show her evolving understanding of herself. The piece avoids melodrama while still conveying emotional depth. The ending feels earned rather than forced, with Dani coming to a place of acceptance and openness rather than a too-neat resolution. The final image of them watching the photograph develop serves as an apt metaphor for their evolving relationship and identities. There are a few moments where the prose becomes slightly purple or overwrought, such as "eyes catching the red light like coals" and "That hits me in the sternum," but these are minor issues in an otherwise well-crafted piece. The narrative successfully adheres to the prompt's requirements, exploring Dani's complex attraction, the tender awkwardness of their conversations, and her internal struggle between taking charge and giving Elliot agency. The chemistry between the characters develops naturally, and the piece effectively captures the uncharted territory they're navigating together. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 79.1
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Stolen Moments in Roma** *Day One: Trevi to Twilight* --- **Scene One: Collision Course** Ben adjusted his wire-rimmed glasses for the third time in five minutes. The midday Roman sun glinted sharply off the cobbles of Piazza di Trevi, and the air shimmered with heat and the chatter of tourists. Balancing a guidebook in one hand and a bottle of lukewarm water in the other, he stood rooted in place, deciphering a passage on Baroque architecture. “Fontana di Trevi,” he mumbled, squinting at the Latin inscription above the fountain. “Giovanni—no, Nicola Salvi?” Then came the rev of an engine, piercing and immediate. “*Attento, scemo!*” someone barked. Ben turned just in time to see a flash of black leather and red helmet as a Ducati skidded to a halt inches from his knees. He stumbled backward, the guidebook flying from his hand and slapping open on the cobbles like a startled bird. “Oh God—I’m terribly sorry, I didn’t mean to—” “*Ma sei pazzo?* Who stands in the middle of the road reading a book?” The rider pulled off her helmet, releasing a wild tumble of dark curls. Her eyes were molten amber and full of exasperation. “I—uh—I thought this was pedestrian-only,” Ben stammered, flushing. She dismounted, her boots clicking confidently. “Only if you’re a Roman. Tourists don’t get immunity.” She kicked the guidebook lightly toward him with the toe of her boot. “British?” “Is it that obvious?” “You look like tea and guilt.” Ben blinked. “That’s...not inaccurate.” She grinned, a flash of teeth and mischief. “I’m Alessandra. You owe me a coffee for almost becoming a hood ornament.” “I—well, yes, I suppose that seems fair.” “Great,” she said, straddling the bike again. “Hop on.” “I—I beg your pardon?” She revved the engine. “You want to buy me coffee, no? Then you ride. Or walk. But I don’t do slow.” His hesitation lasted a full three seconds before he climbed on, awkwardly clutching her waist. “Hold tighter, professore. Rome doesn’t wait for anyone.” --- **Scene Two: The Espresso Gambit** They stopped in Trastevere, at a café hidden behind a crumbling ochre wall. Alessandra ordered two espressi without asking, then sat back with feline ease, legs kicked up on the chair beside her. “So, Ben. What are you in Rome for? Besides almost dying.” “Research. I’m on sabbatical from Cambridge, doing a comparative study of Roman civic planning between the Republic and the early Empire.” Alessandra blinked. “That’s the most British thing I’ve ever heard.” “What do you do?” he asked, sipping his espresso and nearly choking on the bitterness. “I deliver secrets,” she said, deadpan. “Secrets?” “Documents. Parcels. Sometimes pies. Depends on the client.” Ben smiled despite himself. “And do you always kidnap unsuspecting academics?” “Only the cute ones.” He coughed into his cup. --- **Scene Three: The Vatican Heist** By late afternoon, they were weaving through alleys behind the Vatican walls. Alessandra had convinced a sleepy security guard to let them through a side gate with a wink and a rapid-fire lie about a delivery for a cardinal. Ben, red-faced and apologizing in three languages, followed her through the corridors of the Vatican Museums. “Is this even remotely legal?” he whispered. “No one ever died from a little detour,” she whispered back. She stopped in front of a glass case holding a small, silver medallion. As Ben pondered the inscription, Alessandra distracted a nearby guard with a question about the Sistine Chapel’s closing time. When she returned, her hand brushed his, and something cold and metallic passed between their palms. “What—what did you just—?” She winked. “Souvenir.” His jaw dropped. “You didn’t.” “I did.” “You can’t just—Alessandra, that’s theft!” She shrugged. “It was poorly guarded and boring. They’ll never miss it.” Ben stared at her, horrified and intrigued in equal measure. --- **Scene Four: Gelato & Thunder** The first raindrop splashed onto Ben’s nose as they stepped out of a shadowy side street. A second followed. Then, as if cued by an unseen director, the sky cracked open. “Quick!” Alessandra grabbed his hand and yanked him under the striped awning of a gelato shop. The shop was closed for siesta, but the awning was wide and dry. They stood, panting and dripping, inches apart. Ben’s shirt clung to him. Alessandra shook out her curls like a soaked cat. “This is...unexpected,” he said, watching water cascade from the canvas above them. “You Brits bring the rain with you.” He laughed. “In my defense, I was promised sunshine. Rome in June, they said.” She leaned against the wall, her arm brushing his. “You’re not what I expected.” “What *did* you expect?” “A stuffy academic. You are kind of stuffy. But you follow surprisingly well.” “I haven’t the faintest idea where we’ve been.” “Exactly.” Her eyes sparkled. “That’s the point.” He looked at her—really looked at her. The rain framed her like a painting, chaotic and beautiful. Her lips curved up, just slightly, as if she knew exactly what he was thinking. “I’ve never met anyone like you,” he said. “Good,” she replied. “One of me is enough.” --- **Scene Five: Twilight and Temptation** The rain stopped as abruptly as it had begun. The cobblestones steamed. They walked back toward the river, passing shuttered shops and the occasional flurry of laughter from open windows. They paused on the Ponte Sisto bridge, watching the fading orange light ripple over the Tiber. “So,” Ben said, his voice quieter now, “was this a typical day for you?” “No such thing as typical.” “Will I see you again?” She turned to him, face unreadable. “Do you want to?” “Yes.” She stepped closer. “Then maybe you will.” He leaned in, almost without thinking. Her breath was warm with mint and espresso. But she turned at the last second, brushing his cheek with her lips instead. “*Buonanotte, professore*,” she whispered. Then she was gone—boots echoing, helmet swinging from her hand, hair catching the last of the sun. Ben stood alone on the bridge, guidebook forgotten in his satchel, heart racing. He had come to Rome to study the past. But today, he’d collided with something entirely unpredictable: The present. And maybe, something more.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The piece "Stolen Moments in Roma" successfully captures a day-long encounter between two contrasting characters in Rome. The author has structured the narrative as requested, with interconnected short scenes that reveal the personalities of Alessandra and Ben through their interactions. The characterization is generally strong. Alessandra is portrayed as the "fiery, independent Roman woman" specified in the prompt, with her kleptomania subtly revealed through the Vatican scene rather than explicitly stated. Ben's character as the "somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic" comes through clearly in his dialogue and reactions. Their contrasting personalities create an effective dynamic. The prose is generally elegant, with some vivid imagery that brings Rome to life. Descriptions like "The midday Roman sun glinted sharply off the cobbles of Piazza di Trevi" and "The rain framed her like a painting, chaotic and beautiful" effectively establish the setting and mood. However, there are moments where the writing relies on familiar phrases and imagery that don't quite elevate the piece to exceptional status. The dialogue generally works well to establish character and advance the narrative. Lines like "You look like tea and guilt" efficiently communicate Alessandra's sharp wit, while Ben's polite stammering ("I—uh—I thought this was pedestrian-only") effectively conveys his character. However, some exchanges feel slightly formulaic, particularly in the final scene where the dialogue becomes more predictable. The narrative successfully builds tension between the characters, with their chemistry developing naturally through the day's adventures. The ending appropriately leaves things unresolved but promising, with Alessandra maintaining her enigmatic nature while Ben is clearly smitten. The piece does adhere to most instructions, including the requested length and narrative approach. The scenes effectively showcase Rome and the characters' developing relationship. However, while Alessandra does take Ben outside his comfort zone, the "increasingly outlandish situations" mentioned in the prompt could have been more pronounced. The Vatican theft is the main transgressive moment, but the prompt suggests a more escalating series of boundary-pushing events. The narrative flow is generally good, with each scene building logically from the previous one. However, the transitions between scenes are sometimes abrupt, with little explanation of how they got from one location to another, which occasionally disrupts the immersion. Overall, this is a competent and engaging piece that successfully captures the essence of the prompt. It creates a believable encounter between two contrasting characters and effectively uses Rome as a backdrop for their developing connection. While it doesn't reach the heights of exceptional literary fiction, it serves as a solid beginning to what could be a larger story. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 82.2
Prompt:
Cozy spacepunk The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Last Outpost The floor hums low beneath my boots, that familiar purr of the station’s old reactors running just a hair off-kilter. I’m behind the bar, wiping down glasses that don’t need it and letting the night settle into its usual rhythm—half-lazy, half-tense, like the whole place is holding its breath between supply runs and bad decisions. “Hey, Nets!” Grig shouts from the far end of the bar. “You got any of that peach synth left? The one that doesn’t taste like regret?” I shoot him a smirk. “It all tastes like regret, Grig. That’s the point.” He raises his glass in salute anyway, fake peach or not, and I pour him another. The gravity hiccups just then, a gentle lurch that makes the bottle slosh sideways before I steady it. The synth liquor glows faintly, like it’s remembering how to be real fruit. That’s when the stranger walks in. She’s tall, taller than me by a good head, and built like a storm’s eye—quiet, but charged. Her tentacled dreads are in disarray, a few twitching slightly like they’re reacting to the station’s static. Her jacket’s singed at the edges, one boot half-unzipped, and her eyes… her eyes are scanning like she’s counting exits and threats in the same breath. She slides onto the stool in front of me without a word. “Vega whisky, neat,” she says. Voice calm, but hoarse. “Better make that a double.” I nod, grabbing the bottle from below the counter. The label’s half-erased, but the stuff inside’ll kick like a plasma mule. “Rough night?” I ask, setting the glass in front of her. She snorts. “You could say that.” I don’t push. The Outpost isn’t a place where you ask questions—not unless you’re invited. But there’s a tension to her that doesn’t sit right. I’ve seen fugitives, bounty hunters, desperate traders, even a runaway AI once. She’s none of those. Or maybe she’s all of them. She downs the first glass in one go, grimaces, then exhales slow. “So,” I say, casually refilling her drink. “You got a name, or should I just call you Trouble?” That earns me a crooked smile. “Vera.” “Vera. Alright.” I lean on the bar. “Well, welcome to The Last Outpost. We’ve got overpriced drinks, malfunctioning gravity, and a jukebox that only plays spacer blues and pre-war synth pop.” “Sounds like paradise.” “Depends on your definition.” She glances around the room. A couple of off-duty asteroid haulers are playing cards in the corner. One’s cheating, but they haven’t noticed yet. The twins from Deck Twelve are arguing about fusion coils again. Grig’s humming to himself, off-key. Just another night. Then Vera leans in, voice lower. “Listen, I’m looking for someone. Thought maybe you could help.” There it is. The Ask. I raise an eyebrow. “Depends who and depends why.” She slides a small holochip across the bar. It flickers to life—a man’s face. Mid-forties. Eyes like black ice. I don’t recognize him, but that doesn’t mean anything. “Name’s Ral Vex. He was here. Maybe two days ago. Docked a rust-bucket freighter, went by the name ‘Cold Ember.’ Ring any bells?” I study the image, then glance up at her. “Can’t say I’ve seen him. That ship, though… yeah. Docked bay seven. Left yesterday morning.” She leans back, muttering something under her breath in a language I don’t know. “Problem?” I ask. “Yeah,” she says. “He wasn’t supposed to leave without me.” I pause, weighing her tone. “You a partner? Or a bounty hunter?” “Does it matter?” “It does to me.” She stares at me for a beat, then downs the second drink. “Let’s say I’m… someone with unfinished business.” I open my mouth to say something else, but that’s when the lights flicker. Not unusual, but this time they stutter twice, hard, and the background hum of the station skips like a broken rhythm. The gravity lurches again, worse this time, and a few glasses tip over. “Dammit,” I mutter, steadying myself against the bar. Vera looks up sharply. “Is that normal?” I shrug. “Define normal. This place is patched together with more hope than engineering.” But I don’t like it either. Something’s off. Over the comms, a static-cracked voice crackles through. “Attention: All personnel, be advised—unauthorized boarding alert in Sector D-4. Repeat, D-4. Security is en route.” The bar goes quiet. Even the twins stop bickering. Vera’s already standing. “Where’s D-4?” I point toward the maintenance corridor behind the hydroponics vats. “That way. Why?” She doesn’t answer. Just tosses a few credits on the bar and starts moving. “Hey!” I call after her. “Whatever you’re thinking of doing—don’t. You’re not security, and if this guy Vex is mixed up in something—” She stops at the doorway, looks back at me. “Thanks for the drink, Nets. But if he’s here, I need to find him before someone else does.” And then she’s gone. I stare at the credits for a second, then pocket them. Grig sidles up beside me. “New friend?” “Something like that.” “You think she’s the reason for the boarding alert?” “I think,” I say, grabbing a clean glass and pouring myself a shot, “that tonight just stopped being quiet.” And I hate when that happens. The jukebox crackles to life with a sad, synthy wail. The gravity hums weird again, like the station’s holding its breath. Something’s coming. I can feel it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively establishes a cozy spacepunk atmosphere at "The Last Outpost" bar. The author has created a first-person present-tense narrative through Nettle's perspective as requested, with dialogue making up approximately 60% of the text. The word count is appropriate, and the chapter introduces conflict without resolving it. The writing successfully creates a lived-in world with details like the "purr of the station's old reactors running just a hair off-kilter" and the gravity that occasionally "hiccups." These small touches establish the setting as a somewhat ramshackle space station without excessive exposition. The bar environment feels authentic with its cast of background characters like Grig and the twins arguing about fusion coils. The mysterious stranger Vera is introduced effectively, with physical details that suggest her backstory without spelling it out: "tentacled dreads in disarray," "jacket's singed at the edges," and eyes that scan for "exits and threats in the same breath." The dialogue between Nettle and Vera flows naturally and reveals character while advancing the plot. The conflict is introduced through Vera's search for Ral Vex and the "unauthorized boarding alert" that interrupts their conversation. This creates tension and mystery that remains unresolved at the chapter's end, as requested. The final lines effectively build anticipation: "Something's coming. I can feel it." However, there are some weaknesses. While the dialogue is generally strong, a few exchanges feel slightly generic. The character of Nettle, while competently portrayed, could have more distinctive personality traits or quirks to make her more memorable. Some of the space setting elements are familiar tropes (the jukebox, the card players, the malfunctioning gravity), though they're handled well enough not to feel clichéd. The prose occasionally relies on telling rather than showing, particularly when describing Vera's emotional state. For instance, "there's a tension to her that doesn't sit right" could have been conveyed through more specific physical details. Some metaphors, like Vera being "built like a storm's eye," are evocative but could be more original. Overall, this is a solid piece of genre fiction that successfully establishes setting, character, and conflict while adhering to the prompt requirements. It creates an engaging world that readers would likely want to explore further. + Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 82.0
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Chapter 4: French Quarter Ghosts I’m standing on the edge of the French Quarter with a backpack that smells like the inside of a forgotten gym locker and a phone screen that flashes “12%” like it’s some kind of countdown to my own personal apocalypse. The sun is clawing its way up over the buildings, making the streets look like someone poured gold on a trash heap. It’s beautiful and disgusting at the same time. Kinda like me, I guess. I haven’t slept. Not really. I dozed for maybe twenty minutes curled up behind a dumpster behind a beignet place, only to be woken up by some dude cussing out pigeons like they owed him rent. I laughed, and then I cried, and then I laughed again. I’ve been doing that a lot the past two days, like my brain can’t pick a lane. My stomach is a hollow drum. I haven’t eaten since a gas station sandwich yesterday, and I don’t even want to think about what was in it. I need food, a phone charger, and a plan. In that order. But mostly, I need someone to look me in the eye and not see a mistake. “Yo,” a voice says, sharp and raspy like someone who’s smoked more than they’ve spoken. I flinch before I even turn. Reflex. Trauma reflex, I guess. But it’s just a kid—a little older than me, maybe seventeen or eighteen, wearing a denim vest over a hoodie way too thick for this swamp heat. They’ve got a scabbed lip and a piercing in one nostril that looks infected. “Didn’t mean to scare you,” they say, holding up their hands. “Just—you look like you need a win.” I squint at them. “What does that even mean?” They grin, and it softens their whole face. “Means you look like you haven’t eaten since the Bush administration. I’m going to get some food. You coming or what?” I hesitate. Stranger danger. Isn’t that what D.A.R.E. was all about? Except nobody warned me about what to do when your parents suck and your school counselor talks about you like your identity is a behavioral issue. “What’s the catch?” I ask. “No catch,” they say, starting to walk backward toward the alley. “Unless you count the fact that it’s dumpster bagels and not a five-star meal. But I know which bakery throws theirs out early. Real bougie place. They toss ‘em just because they’re a few hours old.” Against every rational part of me, I follow. We sit on the curb in an alley that smells like yeast and piss, munching on bagels that are actually not terrible. Mine has a smear of cream cheese that might have been a mistake, but I’m too hungry to care. “I’m Taylor,” I say, finally. It feels like peeling off a scab—revealing my name. My real name. “Nice. I’m Jules,” they say. “They/them. You?” I nod. “Same.” We bump shoulders in a quiet kind of solidarity. It feels… weird. Good weird. “So what’s your story?” Jules asks, tearing their bagel into pieces. I shrug. “Came out. Got kicked out. Ran away. Ended up here.” “Classic,” they say. “I mean, not good classic. Just—textbook. I did the same thing. Except I came out as nonbinary and also accidentally set my stepdad’s car on fire.” My eyebrows shoot up. “Wait, accidentally?” They smirk. “Let’s go with ‘accidentally.’ It holds up better in court.” We both laugh, and I feel something unclench in my chest. Like maybe I’m not entirely alone in this neon swamp of a city. It’s not all sunshine though. As the day stretches on, things get more complicated. We wander through Jackson Square, where tourists toss sweaty bills into guitar cases and street artists hawk charcoal portraits. Jules knows people. A lot of people. Some of them nod at us like we’re ghosts. Some of them look at me too long, and not in a friendly way. “Stick close,” Jules mutters at one point. “Not everyone’s cool.” “Define ‘not cool,’” I ask. They glance at a wiry guy leaning against a lamppost, skin taut over his bones, eyes glassy. “Some folks out here are predators. Some just desperate. And some… just broken. Like, beyond repair.” I nod. I think about Dad’s face when I told him. How the vein in his forehead bulged like it was trying to escape. The way Mom just stared at her lap, like if she looked at me, she’d catch something. “I don’t think I’m broken,” I say. Quietly. Like I’m still testing the words out loud. Jules looks at me. “You’re not. But even if you were, you’d still deserve to take up space.” That hits me like a sucker punch. I look away, blinking hard. By afternoon, my phone is dead. No charger. No lifeline. No more checking the time like that’ll make it all slow down. I watch the sun claw its way west, dragging a bruised sky behind it. “You got a place to crash?” Jules asks. I shake my head. “You?” They hesitate. “Sort of. There’s this squat near Tchoupitoulas. Some kids stay there. It’s not the Ritz, but it’s dry and no one asks questions.” I weigh my options. Which is to say: I have none. “I’m in.” We walk in silence for a while, the noise of the city buzzing around us like flies. I think about how fast everything unraveled. About how I always thought I’d feel freer when I finally came out. And I do, in a way. But also? I feel like I’m walking a tightrope in the middle of a hurricane. As we reach the squat—an abandoned shotgun house with boards on the windows and graffiti on the siding—I pause. My stomach knots up. “You okay?” Jules asks. “Yeah,” I lie. “Just… wondering if I made the biggest mistake of my life.” They nod. “Probably. But sometimes the wrong road’s the only one that gets you to the right place.” Cryptic. But maybe true. Inside, the place smells like mold and sweat and something vaguely herbal I don’t want to think about. There are a few others—kids around our age. One of them gives me a nod. Another doesn’t even look up. I sit on the floor next to Jules, wrapping my arms around my knees. I’m nowhere near okay. But for the first time in a long time, I don’t feel completely invisible. Tomorrow’s a problem for Future Taylor. Tonight, I’m just here. Still breathing. Still me.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing successfully establishes Taylor's character through first-person narration that blends vulnerability with defensive humor. The prose has a raw, authentic quality that suits the protagonist and situation. The story adheres well to the prompt requirements, incorporating Taylor's internal monologue, mixed tense, and introducing another runaway character (Jules) with their own issues. The setting of New Orleans is utilized effectively through sensory details like the smell of beignets and descriptions of Jackson Square. Character development is one of the stronger aspects. Taylor feels like a real teenager—scared but trying to project toughness, making impulsive decisions while being self-aware enough to question them. Jules serves as an effective foil and potential ally, with their own backstory hinted at but not fully revealed, maintaining some mystery. The dialogue between Taylor and Jules rings true for teenagers in their situation—a mix of wariness, dark humor, and occasional vulnerability. Their conversation about identity feels natural rather than preachy, with lines like "You're not. But even if you were, you'd still deserve to take up space" carrying emotional weight without becoming melodramatic. The imagery is vivid and often metaphorical: "making the streets look like someone poured gold on a trash heap. It's beautiful and disgusting at the same time. Kinda like me, I guess." These descriptions effectively convey both the physical setting and Taylor's emotional state. However, there are some weaknesses. The pacing feels slightly rushed in the middle section, with the transition from meeting Jules to wandering through Jackson Square lacking some connective tissue. Some of the metaphors, while evocative, occasionally veer toward being overwrought ("the sun claw its way west, dragging a bruised sky behind it"). The ending, while not unrealistically positive, resolves a bit too neatly for a first day on the streets, with Taylor finding shelter and a potential friend so quickly. The piece could benefit from more exploration of the dangers Jules warns about, as this threat is mentioned but not really demonstrated in the narrative. Additionally, while Taylor's emotional state is well-conveyed, their physical discomfort from being on the streets (beyond hunger) could be more present. Overall, this is a compelling character study that effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen in crisis. The writing balances raw emotion with moments of connection and hope, creating a narrative that feels authentic to the character's experience while maintaining reader engagement. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 6.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 87.0
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**My Apocalypse Buddy** The morning began, as most did in the post-technological collapse, with the sound of something important breaking very far away and not nearly far enough. Midas squinted up at the sky, which was the sort of sullen grey that suggested it had overslept and wasn’t particularly pleased about having to work today. A low rumble echoed across the ruined cityscape. “That was either another substation blowing or the Church of the Eternal Wifi experimenting with prayer-based routers again,” he muttered, rubbing sleep from his eyes with one hand and swatting at a suspiciously large mosquito with the other. “Either way, it’s probably not good news.” On the table beside him, Chewy blinked awake. His eyes—two tiny, LED-lit orbs embedded in a plush, soot-streaked koala—flickered to a cautious amber. “Don’t start,” Midas said, already rummaging through a dented tin marked *Emergency Sardines (Possibly Edible)*. “Yes, I know we’re out of batteries. Yes, I know we have to leave the bunker. And yes, I know you’re technically not even supposed to be sentient. But you are, and here we are.” Chewy’s eyes went briefly red, which meant either ‘I told you so’ or ‘I disapprove of your fashion choices today.’ It was hard to tell. The old firmware was never designed for sarcasm. “Today’s mission,” Midas announced, “is simple. We go to the ruins of the MegaMart on 5th and Plunder, avoid the scavenger cults, negotiate with the vending machine warlords, and acquire a fresh solar coil. Easy.” The last time Midas had said “easy,” they’d ended up trapped inside a sentient compost heap for three days. Chewy’s eyes turned a skeptical purple. “I mean it this time,” Midas added. “No detours. No ‘interesting’ side quests.” --- The ruins of the MegaMart loomed like a cautionary tale told by a building that had fallen into bad company. Half its walls had collapsed under the weight of centuries of discount bulk items. Somewhere, a rogue shopping cart squealed in the wind. Midas crouched beside a scorched mannequin in what used to be the fashion aisle and whispered, “Okay, the solar coils were in Electronics, past the perilous terrain of Half-Price Linens. Shouldn’t be too hard—” A sudden screech cut through the air. A trio of scavengers in mismatched armor—made mostly from toaster parts and misplaced ambition—burst from behind a display of expired protein bars. “INTRUDERS!” the lead one yelled, brandishing a spatula like a sword. “By decree of the Great Coupon, this place is ours!” Midas groaned and ducked as Chewy launched himself from his backpack with surprising speed for a creature filled mostly with stuffing and ancient servos. The koala’s eyes flared bright blue—battle mode. Or possibly disco mode. Again, hard to tell. Chewy landed squarely on the lead scavenger’s face, emitting a burst of garbled 1990s catchphrases. “CUDDLE ATTACK!” he bellowed, though the voice module had degraded enough that it came out more like “KUDDLE ACK–ACK!” The scavenger flailed. His companions slipped on a pile of decorative soaps and vanished behind a collapsing shelf. “That… went better than expected,” Midas said, blinking. Chewy stared at him, eyes now pulsing green—self-satisfaction. Or mild nausea. They made it to Electronics without further incident, apart from a brief detour through the Housewares section, where Midas nearly lost a toe to an aggressive blender cult. But the solar coils were there, nestled behind a barricade of obsolete DVD players and a very confused raccoon. “Look at it,” Midas whispered reverently. “A genuine SunSucker 3000. We could power the bunker for weeks!” He reached for it just as something clicked ominously. A trap. The floor gave way. They tumbled into darkness. --- They landed in what appeared to be a forgotten employee break room, now repurposed by the Children of the Pop-Tart. Hooded figures surrounded them, chanting in a language that sounded suspiciously like bad advertising jingles. “Ye who seek the power of the Sun must pay the Toll of Toaster Strudel,” intoned the High Pastry Prophet, a woman with a colander on her head and jam smeared across her cheeks. “We don’t want trouble,” Midas said quickly, holding up Chewy like a badge of office. “We’re just here for the solar coil. My buddy here’s an animatronic from the Before Times. He can sing the forbidden theme song of the Breakfast Isles.” Chewy’s eyes blinked in confused orange. “Just go with it,” Midas muttered. Chewy sighed—he had somehow developed the capacity to sigh—and emitted a garbled, staticky rendition of *“It’s morning somewhere, pop one in!”*. There was a pause. The Children stared. Then they erupted into cheers. “You have the Blessing of Kellogg!” the Prophet declared. “Take the Coil and go, Friends of Frosted Wisdom!” --- They emerged into daylight, bruised, jam-smeared, and carrying the solar coil like a trophy. Midas limped. Chewy’s left ear twitched erratically. He now smelled faintly of raspberry. They made it halfway home before the solar coil, perhaps offended by their misuse of sacred breakfast rituals, shorted out and exploded in a puff of ozone and existential disappointment. “…That could have gone worse,” Midas said. Chewy’s eyes turned an exhausted grey. A few sparks popped from his nostrils. By the time they reached the bunker, the sky had turned a shade of purple usually reserved for overripe fruit and bad omens. Rain began to fall, oily and insistent. Midas flopped into their one surviving armchair. Chewy collapsed beside him with a mechanical wheeze. “Well,” Midas said, “we’re out of sardines, out of power, and possibly now being worshipped as breakfast demigods.” Chewy’s eyes flickered. Then turned pink. Laughter. Or maybe indigestion. “Tomorrow,” Midas declared, “we try the pharmacy ruins. I hear they still have Twinkies.” Chewy blinked once. Red. Absolutely not.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its absurdist post-apocalyptic setting and deadpan humor. The piece follows the prompt's requirements by featuring Midas (the hapless protagonist) and Chewy (an animo-tronic koala) as they embark on a mission that predictably goes sideways. The writing demonstrates strong command of Pratchett's distinctive style through clever turns of phrase ("the sky, which was the sort of sullen grey that suggested it had overslept and wasn't particularly pleased about having to work today") and absurdist worldbuilding elements like the "Church of the Eternal Wifi" and "Children of the Pop-Tart." The humor is consistently dry and understated, with running gags about Chewy's ambiguous LED eye colors and Midas's penchant for understatement. Character-wise, both Midas and Chewy are well-established. Midas embodies the classic Pratchett protagonist who maintains a weary pragmatism in the face of absurdity. Chewy, despite limited communication abilities, conveys personality through his LED expressions and actions. Their relationship feels lived-in and authentic. The plot follows the prompt's structure perfectly: beginning with deliberation about their mission, detailing how it goes sideways (falling into the trap, encountering the Pop-Tart cult), and returning them to home base worse for wear (bruised, jam-smeared, and without a functioning solar coil). The worldbuilding is particularly strong, efficiently establishing a bizarre post-collapse world with cults formed around everyday objects, dangerous expeditions for basic supplies, and the strange juxtaposition of ancient technology with primitive survival. The writer creates memorable images and concepts without overexplaining. The dialogue is sparse but effective, capturing Midas's resigned attitude and the absurdity of their encounters. The prose flows naturally with varied sentence structures and well-timed humor. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Some readers might want more emotional depth or character development, though this isn't necessarily expected in a Pratchett-style piece focused on humor and adventure. The ending is somewhat abrupt, though it does complete the narrative arc as requested. Overall, this is an excellent execution of the prompt that captures Pratchett's style while creating an original and engaging short story. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 86.3
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**Title: Love in the Limelight** **Scene: “Between the Stacks”** **Location: Cardiff, Wales – a small, independent bookstore tucked between a chippy and a florist, called “Thistle & Quill.” Rain drums steadily against the windowpanes.** --- **[The bell above the door jangles violently. A gust of wind follows a man inside—tall, tousle-haired, sunglasses still on despite the grey skies. He scans the place quickly, then ducks behind a rotating rack of postcards.]** **BOOKSTORE OWNER (nonplussed, folding a receipt at the counter):** …You know we’re not a safehouse, right? **ACTOR (peering over the rack, cheeky grin):** That depends who’s chasing me. If it’s the press, yes. If it’s an ex, possibly. If it’s an angry director with a wine glass in hand—definitely. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** I see. So, just the usual Monday morning crowd, then? **ACTOR (straightening up, removing sunglasses with a flourish):** Guilty as charged. *[extends a hand, all gleaming teeth and boyish charm]* I’m— **BOOKSTORE OWNER (not taking the hand):** I know who you are. **ACTOR (momentarily thrown):** Ah. Right. That’s usually followed by a gasp and maybe a selfie request, but… I’ll take mysterious indifference. It’s very Cardiff of you. **BOOKSTORE OWNER (dryly):** We take pride in our restraint. You’re dripping on my floor, by the way. **ACTOR (glancing down at his soaked coat):** Right. Sorry. Bit of a mad dash through Queen Street. Paparazzi popped up like mushrooms after rain. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** They tend to do that when someone’s staged a public breakup in front of the Millennium Centre. **ACTOR (feigned outrage):** Staged? I’ll have you know that argument was entirely improvised. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** Oh, then your BAFTA’s overdue. **ACTOR (laughs, genuinely):** You’re sharp. I like that. *[pauses, scanning the shop]* This place is… charming. Smells like tea and neglected ambition. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** That’ll be the poetry section. **ACTOR:** Do you do hiding services, then? You know—“Witness Protection, but for celebrities with wounded egos”? **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** Depends. Do you buy books? **ACTOR (mock offense):** Do I—! Of course I do. I’ve read... loads of them. Tons. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** Name three. **ACTOR (beat):** The Great Gatsby. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** Predictable. **ACTOR:** Harry Potter. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** Safe. **ACTOR (grinning):** And... *[eyes scanning shelves wildly]* The... uh... The Subtle Knife? **BOOKSTORE OWNER (arching an eyebrow):** You just read that title off the spine behind me. **ACTOR (laughing again, a bit sheepish):** Alright, you caught me. I’m more of a script guy. But I like the idea of books. The smell. The weight. **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** You like the aesthetic of intelligence, then? **ACTOR (mock wounded):** Ouch. You wound me, Miss…? **BOOKSTORE OWNER:** You first. **ACTOR:** Leo Hale. **BOOKSTORE OWNER (deadpan):** Yes, I know. Your face is on the side of every bus in town. I assume that’s not a coincidence. **LEO (grinning):** Nope. That’s strategic narcissism. So—your turn. **BOOKSTORE OWNER (after a pause):** Elin. Elin Morgan. **LEO:** Elin. That’s lovely. Welsh, obviously. Strong. Quietly poetic. **ELIN:** Are you flirting with me, Mr. Hale? **LEO (smirking):** I haven’t decided yet. Would it work? **ELIN:** Unlikely. **LEO (playful sigh):** I was afraid of that. You’ve got that look—like you’ve read enough Brontë to be immune to bad boys with good bone structure. **ELIN (half-smile):** You think you’re a bad boy? **LEO (leans on the counter):** I play one on telly. And I’ve got the tabloid clippings to prove it. **ELIN:** Fake fights. Staged romances. Carefully leaked scandals. Honestly, it’s a bit tired. **LEO (with a flash of vulnerability):** You think it’s all fake? **ELIN (softens slightly):** I think you hide behind the performance. I think you’re used to people falling over themselves to impress you. And I think... *[pauses]* you’re more interesting when you stop trying to be. **LEO (quiet, surprised):** Huh. **ELIN (changing the subject):** There’s a chair by the travel section. You can wait there until the coast is clear. But no autographs, and no pretending to read if you’re just going to take selfies. **LEO (grinning again, but gentler now):** You really are immune, aren’t you? **ELIN (retreating behind the counter):** Didn’t say that. **LEO (pauses mid-step):** Oh? **ELIN (not meeting his eyes):** Just said it was unlikely to work. There’s a difference. **LEO (with a slow, real smile):** Right. Got it. Unlikely. Not impossible. **[Elin busies herself with a stack of returns, her cheeks faintly pink. Leo watches her for a moment longer than necessary, then wanders off toward the travel books, whistling low under his breath.]** **[The bell above the door jangles again. Elin glances up, but it’s only the wind. Or perhaps something else stirring.]** --- **Scene ends.**
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively creates a romantic scene in a Welsh bookstore between a famous actor and a bookstore owner. The writing demonstrates strong command of dialogue, which carries most of the narrative as requested, and successfully establishes the characters' distinct voices. The actor, Leo Hale, is well-characterized as the charming rogue with a fragile ego. His dialogue reveals his need to be liked, shown through his persistent attempts to charm Elin despite her initial resistance. The writer effectively shows his momentary vulnerability when Elin suggests his public persona might be fake, creating a crack in his practiced facade. Elin, the bookstore owner, is portrayed convincingly as someone outwardly immune to Leo's charm while inwardly affected. Her dry wit and sharp responses establish her character, while subtle cues like her "cheeks faintly pink" and admission that his charm working is "unlikely, not impossible" reveal her inner attraction. The dialogue is the strongest element of the piece. It crackles with tension and wit, establishing character through speech patterns rather than exposition. Leo's lines are smooth and practiced, while Elin's are direct and unimpressed. Their verbal sparring effectively builds the romantic tension. The setting is economically established in the header and through small details throughout. The writer doesn't overdo the Welsh setting but includes enough touches (references to Cardiff, Queen Street, the Millennium Centre) to ground it in place. The scene successfully creates the "undercurrent of unspoken chemistry" requested in the prompt. The dynamic works because Leo's charm offensive is genuinely derailed by Elin's immunity, which provokes a more authentic interest from him. Meanwhile, Elin's inner conflict is subtly conveyed. There are a few minor weaknesses. The prose occasionally becomes a bit too self-aware or clever, particularly in some of Leo's lines. The ending, while appropriate for the scene, is slightly on-the-nose with its metaphor about "something else stirring." However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-executed piece. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating engaging characters and dialogue that effectively conveys the romantic tension between them. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 83.4
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold was too quiet. Aya pressed her gloved hand to the heavy iron door, the cold of it seeping through the leather like a whispered warning. Behind her, Katra shifted uneasily, one hand on the hilt of her dagger. Simeon, ever the pragmatist, checked the charge in his aether pistol, its brass casing catching the dim glow of the gas lamps overhead. The silence was unnatural. The Morska guildhall was never silent — not even at its deepest depths. There was always some sound: the creak of ancient pipes, the scuttling of rats fat on smuggled cheese, the low mutters of guards playing dice in the dark. But now… nothing. Aya pushed the door open, and the scent hit her first: hot oil, old blood, and the sharp, metallic tang of ozone — the unmistakable signature of immateria magick recently used. The stone walls glistened with moisture, and the gas lamps flickered in their sconces, casting long, shuddering shadows across the corridor like the arms of something dying. They stepped into the vault antechamber — and stopped cold. Atop the dais where the Scythan artifact should have rested, the blackstone pedestal was empty. In its place stood a woman wrapped in shadow and smoke. The Guildmaster. Alive. Unbound. Unsmiling. Her name was never spoken aloud, not in the alleys nor the parlours nor beneath the damp arches of the underhold. To most, she was only ever "the Widow." And now, she stood with her spine straight as a blade, her cloak of black velvet trailing like spilled ink, and her eyes—Gods above—her eyes were silvered with the unmistakable shimmer of possession. Behind her, two bodyguards stepped forward, both of them towering brutes armored in soot-stained boiler suits, the hiss of their aether-pressurised gauntlets filling the room with menace. One carried a poleaxe with brass tubing running its length, the other a repeater pistol of Scythan make, the kind forbidden by Imperial decree. “Well,” the Widow said, her voice smooth as lacquered wood. “Isn’t this a charming little betrayal.” Simeon raised his pistol, but the Widow simply looked at him, and the weapon snapped in half with a sound like ice cracking. Aya’s breath caught. Not sorcery — not like hers. This was deeper. Older. The kind of magick the priests burned libraries to forget. Katra swore under her breath, drawing her dagger, but the two guards moved faster than seemed natural. In a blur, Simeon was disarmed and slammed to the ground, his breath knocked from his lungs in a wheeze. Katra’s blade skittered across the stone floor, and she was pinned to the wall by a gauntleted hand the size of a dinner plate. Aya, for her part, stood still. Her heart was a drumbeat in her throat. She didn’t draw on the immateria. Not here. Not with the Widow watching. The shadows in the corners of the room pulsed in time with her fear, eager to be summoned. “You’ve worn that mask for a long time, girl,” the Widow purred, descending the dais like a queen at court. “I daresay I’ve enjoyed watching you. So clever. So bold. So very, very foolish.” Aya said nothing. Her mask — a half-face affair of burnished bronze and black velvet — did little to hide her trembling jaw. “Take it off,” the Widow said. Aya hesitated. For a heartbeat, she considered running — drawing on the immateria and letting the shadows have her. It would be quick. It would be final. But she didn’t. She reached up and unfastened the clasps. The mask fell away with a soft clink, revealing pale skin, high cheekbones, and eyes too sharp for her age. The Widow smiled without warmth. “Ah. The darling daughter of the late Lady Virelle. I remember the trial. Your mother screamed beautifully.” Aya’s stomach turned. “And yet,” she said, voice steady despite the bile rising in her throat, “here you are, wielding the very magick they hanged her for.” The Widow laughed — a low, rich sound that echoed around the chamber. “Oh, child. The difference is that I know when to let the mob believe they’ve won.” Katra struggled against her captor’s grip. “If you’re going to kill us, get it over with.” The Widow turned her gaze on Katra, and the thief fell silent under the weight of it. Aya stepped forward. “Wait. I can be useful.” The Widow arched a brow. “Useful?” “I’m worth more alive than dead,” Aya said quickly. “The aristocracy would pay dearly for my return. My father commands half the merchant fleet in the northern isles. He has friends in Parliament.
